that so what I mean is when you write programs you get a lot of type errors uh
and the reason that that's cool is that type errors happen at compile time not at run time and in the context of
embedded that means they happen on your nice desktop computer not on the microcontroller because when stuff goes
wrong on microcontrollers as we'll talk about later even being able to figure out what goes wrong is like hard so if
it's a nice error message that happens up front then uh you know that's just a much better experience and a much better
like learning situation for a lot of people um and related to that part of the reason why that's good is also because the rust team is very dedicated to the
idea that compiler error messages are important and something they invest time into so there's just like a general policy of the rest project that if an
error message just confusing file a bug and we need to make it better ironically Russ error messages at this
point are generally so good that I blindly trust them and so the one percent of the time when they're bad it
can lead you down the bad path because you're still like if you haven't programmed arrest before a lot of times the compiler will say hey here's a
problem but then it also will literally suggest to you the fix that will make it work and so you kind of get into this
habit of it's like oh by the way I see what you did there and also like it might be this and it turns out it's right often enough that uh that's a
really helpful like way to learn um so I think that's very good uh the
the third bullet point Library design we're going to talk about using some libraries a little later in this talk

mainstream ever since Apple started using arm processors instead of x86 processors the idea of a cross compiling
is instead of taking the code and building it from my machine I'm going to build it for a machine that's a totally
different kind of processor right like my little board that I've plugged into my computer like this is an x86 computer and that's an arm chip so they just like
literally don't work the same as the processor as on like the processor level so we need to expressly tell the the
computer hey compile for this particular architecture not for the one you're running on and so that's like a really
big thing this is another example where tooling is much better in Rust than in other places um actually that's not always entirely
too but it's also like clang so let's not even get rest in the equation let's just talk about clang versus GCC really quick after 2 C and C plus plus
compilers GCC makes you build your own copy of the compiler specifically to
cross compile so it only knows one input and one output so if you want to start going from x86 to arm you have to build
your own GCC or download a pre-built package of it but the point is a separate compiler the way that clang and
also rust work is that every compiler is also a cross compiler so you just pass it a flag saying please compile for this
